subject: Add cleanwait timeout cleanup process
commit_message:
Add cleanwait timeout cleanup process

Previously, if a node in a cleaning state timed out, the timeout
process would not purge certain items from the node's configuration
which resulted in a short circuiting of the logic cleaning being
retried. This was a result of the node clean_step configuration
not being purged upon a timeout occuring.

This change adds a wrapper method around the cleaning failure
error handler to allow the _fail_if_in_state method to call
the error handler, since error handler syntax is not uniform
and the _fail_if_in_state cannot pass arguments.

It also changes the cleaning error handler to permit the error
handler to delete the node clean_step, and cleaning related
driver_internal_info configuration from a node in the event
the node in in CLEANFAIL state.

subject: Run flavor migrate on upgrades.
commit_message:
Run flavor migrate on upgrades.

Force upgrades to Liberty to step through Kilo and force Kilo upgrades to
migrate flavor information. The flavor migration needs to be run with a
Kilo tool set as the flavor migration option appears to have been removed
in Liberty . The charm now run the flavor migration if the current
deployment is Kilo and the user is migrating to a higher release.

When an instance is created on Icehouse the flavour ID is stored in a table
called instance_system_metadata. Kilo (or maybe Juno) creates a new table
in the nova database called instance_extra. For new instances created after
upgrading to Kilo the flavour information goes into the instance_extra
table not instance_system_metadata. It is a prerequisite for upgrading to
Liberty that this flavour data has been moved from instance_system_metadata
to instance_extra. At upgrade at this point will fail because the instance
created when the system was on Icehouse has its flavour information in the
wrong place.

Change-Id: If486372b05d165bd17fa9466b435f22088532d89
Closes-Bug: #1580698

subject: Add hook scripts for the Jenkins job for Tricircle tempest
commit_message:
Add hook scripts for the Jenkins job for Tricircle tempest

1.What is the purpose of this patch set?
The Tricircle project doesn't provide integration test yet.
To achieve integration test, the Tricircle needs to provide
hook scripts for the Jenkins job to execute the test. The Tricircle
integration test Jenkins job will be configured in

https://github.com/openstack-infra/project-config/tree/master/jenkins/jobs

A Jenkins job patch will be submited to project-config once
this patch is merged. Without the hook scripts provided in this
patch, the Jenkins job configured in project-config is not able
to be executed successfully.

After the autotimc Jenkins job is established, all new patches
sumitted to the Tricircle should pass the integration test, i.e. the
test is also the gate test for a new patch.

For example, for cinder volume type patch, currently no integration
test is provided, we don't know the patch work or not.

As new features added to the Tricircle, integration test cases from
the Tempest for OpenStack Nova/Cinder/Neutron could be added to the
post_test_hook.sh, to test the features added to the Tricircle is
correct or not.

2.What is the benefit of this patch set for the Tricircle project?
Reuse OpenStack Nova/Cinder/Neutron tempest test cases, and provide
integration gate test for new patches.

3.What is the platform you tested it out?
After the Jenkins job patch is merged, the test will be executed in
the OpenStack CI pipeline, and as one of the gate test for a new
patch. CI pipeline will be triggered by gerrit review process, and
the test will be executed in the devstack VM(booted by CI pipeline).

http://docs.openstack.org/infra/system-config/jenkins.html

subject: Use any disk for /boot regardless of its size
commit_message:
Use any disk for /boot regardless of its size

Apparently, the disks which're bigger than 2T were excluded from list
of bootable disks if possible. Just because in the past, those disks
were unrecognized by BIOS (or UEFI under CSM).

In fact, it was just misconfiguration of RAID controller or BIOS
itself.

GRUB uses BIOS INT13h in order to find all available disks.
Therefore, unless particular disk is not configured as 'bootable',
there's no change for GRUB to find it.

One should configure hardware in the following way assuming that
the first disk (hd0) is bootable and is used for operating system
purposes.
In case of hardware RAID, FC multipath or any other HBA, the disk
(or lun, or whatever) which was configured as 'bootable' will be
reported as hd0 via INT13h. So, GRUB will be able to boot from it.

DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1588260

subject: Use correct keystone auth parameters
commit_message:
Use correct keystone auth parameters

Neutron Metadata Agent uses the authentication parameters as a fallback
method in the event that communication with Neutron API over RPC fails.
In the fallback case, it looks for Keystone v2.0 authentication
credentials but looks for them under the names:

- admin_user
- admin_password
- admin_tenant_name

Which can be the service user information. We were previously
configuring Keystone v3 authentication parameters in this space and this
causes 400 Bad Request responses from Keystone (since the Agent has null
values for those config options).

Further, the metadata agent does not need to use the admin URL to
authenticate. Instead, it can use the internal URL to retrieve its token
and then authenticate to Neutron API over HTTP.

Change-Id: Ib413d3f3f3351bef29b0e68a2cfb96b7f3dff3c3
Closes-bug: 1591282
Closes-bug: 1590957
(cherry picked from commit b271778e16a83aefb0e704a9aca0ef09f405084c)

subject: Make sure AZAwareWeightScheduler base on weight of agent
commit_message:
Make sure AZAwareWeightScheduler base on weight of agent

Problem details can be found in bug description. AZ here stands
available zone.

heapq.heapify() will sort tuple according to the first element. If
the first element is equal, then the second element is used. When
creating a new network, each AZ doesn't hold the network. So, the
AZ handling list is actually a name ordered list. As a consequence,
when creating a new network, a certain AZ will always be used,
for example, 'nova1' in ['nova1', 'nova2', 'nova3'].

This patch will sort the resource_hostable_agents firstly, so that
the AZ that holds dhcp-agent with least load comes first. Then use
min() to get the first AZ.

subject: Switch to use CA certificate for SAML signing
commit_message:
Switch to use CA certificate for SAML signing

`sigver.read_cert_from_file` expects the pem type certificate's
content holds plain certificate information, which means it 's
started from
`-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----`
or
`-----BEGIN PUBLIC KEY-----`

And ended with
`-----END CERTIFICATE-----`
or
`-----END PUBLIC KEY-----`

But the public key certificate used as the default also contains,
- Signature Algorithm
- Public Key
- Signature Algorithm
- Subject etc.

This will cause the certificate is not a valid certificate and
thus `CertificateError` will be raised in this case.

This patch change to use the CA certificate for saml signing which
only holds the plain certificate information as stated above, so the
default configuration will work as well.

Closes-Bug: #1507456
Change-Id: I648880237d21b00cca4a976fe65bf0e23d41d677

This patch enhances FC multipath by adding target_luns
to FibreChannelConnector.

Only target_luns is added because FCConnector has already treated
multiple wwn information in target_wwn.

target_luns differs among lun-masking tables (lun id tables)
in the following conditions.

1)
Storage/Driver manages lun-masking tables for each FC ports.

2)
The unused youngest number in the table is assigned to
the lun which is registered to each lun-masking table as lun id
because it makes the driver's implementation simple.

3)
User configures lun-masking manually for non-openstack purpose.
(I mean that when user configures lun-masking for some ports(not all)
the unused youngest number differs among lun-masking tables.)

And, to keep compatibility for the volume driver which does not
require such mechanism, if conn info does not include 'target_luns',
then target_luns is set to '[target_lun] * len(target_wwn)'.

subject: [DNM|TESTONLY] NeutronDbObject concurrency issues
commit_message:
[DNM|TESTONLY] NeutronDbObject concurrency issues

Open for discussion [3].

This patch set displays some potential concurrency issues with the
current NeutronDbObject implementation. In it's current state, it is up
to the NeutronDbObject subclasses or their users to properly handle
concurrency.

Further patch sets will provide acquire_object/acquire_objects
contextmanager methods to the NeutronDbObject class. These methods are
to be used in place of get_object/get_objects whenever the user intends
to make changes to the object. These methods would start an
autonested_transaction.

There are (at least) two potential options for the implementation:

1. Based on the DB locks (e.g. SELECT FOR UPDATE/SqlAlchemy
   with_for_update).

   pros:
     - the object is guaranteed to not be changed while within the
       context

   cons:
     - prone to deadlocks ([1] and potentially when locking multiple
       objects)

2. Lock-free CAS based on object version counter. Can use SqlAlchemy
   version counter [2] or add our own. If conflicting changes are
   detected upon exiting the context (i.e. version counter held differs
   from the one in the DB), will raise OSLO RetryRequest exception.

   pros:
     - does not require locking

   cons:
     - require an additional field in the models

While opt.2 only prevents the conflicting changes, but does not
guarantee that the object does not change while within the context,
opt.1 may seem preferential. But even with opt.1 the user should not
expect that the changes made to the object while within the context will
get to the database as the autonested_transaction could fail on
flush/commit.

[1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OpenStack_and_SQLAlchemy#MySQLdb_.2B_eventlet_.3D_sad
[2] http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_0_9/orm/versioning.html

[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-May/094862.html

Change-Id: I2b406fa70e5143e20fc96b32cf08aa61490bcf6a

subject: Fuel plugin builder validator refactored
commit_message:
Fuel plugin builder validator refactored

Some FPB changes is required to make plugins v5.0 validation.

Now it is more easy to:
- to validate folders
- to perform nested validations
- to output arbitry messages
- to collect full report not stopping validation on errors

Code changes:
- Inspections and Checks is introduced.
  Checks is a bubbles of validator business logic that could be runned
  against abstract path or explicit file resource. They are easy to
  reuse and unit-test.
  Inspections runs set of Checks against given path. So now the
  validator itself is just declaration of inspections with setting
  and (almost) don't contain any logic.
- ReportNode inroduced.
  Reports is the unit of the validator output pipeline, they
  could be combined in report tree. Report tree being rendering
  forms the validator output. Checks and Validators are returning
  separate branches of this tree. Also ReportNode contain shortcuts
  for easy text messages creation and falure messages statistics.

subject: crypto - revert EC container update overrides to X-Backend-*
commit_message:
crypto - revert EC container update overrides to X-Backend-*

We previously changed all container update override headers to use an
X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override- namespace so that they
would be persisted, replacing the former
X-Backend-Container-Update-Override- names. The only existing usage
prior to encryption was for EC PUTs. We made sure that the object
server would still accept the X-Backend-Container-Update-Override-
headers in case a proxy had not been upgraded. In that case the object
server already has workarounds for those headers not being persisted.

However, the previous change did not cater for a proxy server being
upgraded before an object server. The proxy server would start to use
X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override- headers in EC PUT requests
which the older version object server would not recognise for the
purposes of constructing container update headers.

This patch reverts the proxy controller to use
X-Backend-Container-Update-Override- headers in EC PUT
requests. Encryption middleware (and any future usages of overrides)
continues to use X-Object-Sysmeta-Container-Update-Override-
headers. Since that is a new feature that must be explicitly
configured into existing systems it is more reasonable to assume that
all servers will be upgraded before introducing the feature, and with
it the new header usage.

Change-Id: Ife9f5084a799b339f2d6b176ae7fad4497b19d67

subject: Aodh upgrade heat template and manifests to replace ceilometer alarms
commit_message:
Aodh upgrade heat template and manifests to replace ceilometer alarms

This step needs to be run after the major-upgrade-pacemaker-init.yaml
step. It is split in three parts:

1) The first part is a shell script that disables old ceilometer alarm
pacemaker resources and removes related constraints and packages.

2) Here we run a small puppet manifest that configures aodh under httpd
via wsgi. We explicitly disable httpd's restart because by restarting
httpd manually via systemctl we risk that pacemaker's monitoring action
might happen exactly at that point and hence it will notice httpd being
down and initiate a stop/start action which will make the puppet
manifest fail. Also note that aodh uses the same backend as ceilometer.
This ensures the existing ceilometer alarms work without any need for
migration in aodh.

3) The last step is another small puppet manifest that takes
care of creating the aodh notifier, evaluator and listener pacemaker
resources and their constraints. We also restart the httpd-clone
resource to make sure that httpd is restarted with the new aodh under
wsgi configuration. This is in a separate step because we need the
guarantee that a) all packages are installed on all nodes before
creating the pacemaker resources and b) all wsgi configuration is
completed on all nodes before we restart httpd.

The rationale for this approach is that we want this
step to be verifiable on its own. That is the reason we actually
restart httpd at the very end. We want to make sure we can
verify aodh is working correctly under httpd before doing
the next upgrade steps. Note that we also include the horizon
classes in both puppet manifests in order to avoid wiping out
the horizon vhost configuration from apache.

Closes-bug: #1581504
